from __future__ import division
import plotly.figure_factory as ff
from plotly.offline import download_plotlyjs, init_notebook_mode, plot, iplot

regions = pd.read_csv('../input/noc_regions.csv')

source.201a6645:
summer_gold_man = summer.loc[(summer['Sex'] == 'M') & (summer['Medal'] == 'Gold')]
summer_gold_man = summer_gold_man.groupby( [ "region"] ).count().reset_index().sort_values(by = 'Medal', ascending=False).head(10)

g = sns.catplot(x = 'region', y = 'Medal', data = summer_gold_man,
                height=9, kind="bar", palette="OrRd")

g.despine(left=True)
g.set_xlabels("Top 10 countries")
g.set_ylabels("Number of gold Medals")
plt.title('Gold medals for men by country')

source.a2ec563e:
map_P = summer.groupby( [ "region"] ).count().reset_index()
map_P = map_P.rename(columns = {'region':'Country'})
map_P = map_P.drop(['ID','Name', 'Sex', 'Age', 'Age', 'Height', 'Weight', 'Team', 'NOC', 'Games', 'Year', 'Season', 'City', 'Sport', 'Event', 'notes'], axis = 1)


map_P = dict(type = 'choropleth', locations = map_P['Country'],locationmode = 'country names',z = map_P['Medal'], text = map_P['Country'],colorbar = {'title':'World Happiness Score'})
layout = dict(title = 'Countries with more medals', geo = dict(showframe = False))
map_P = go.Figure(data = [map_P], layout=layout)

iplot(map_P)

source.0c606eb9:
from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D
sns.set_style("whitegrid")

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(13,10))
ax  = fig.gca(projection = "3d")
plot = ax.scatter(gold_medal_NotNull[gold_medal_NotNull["Age"].notnull()]["Height"],
                  gold_medal_NotNull[gold_medal_NotNull["Age"].notnull()]["Weight"],
                  gold_medal_NotNull[gold_medal_NotNull["Age"].notnull()]["Age"],
                  cmap = "jet",
                  linewidth = .1,
                  edgecolor = "k",
                  s = 60,
                  color = 'r'
                 )

ax.set_xlabel("Height")
ax.set_ylabel("Weight")
ax.set_zlabel("Age")
plt.title("Correlation for height,weight and age " )
plt.show()

source.14490e73:
Hi there!

Today i want to make data analysis about the Olympic Games from 1896 to 2016

This time i've picked this data set because sport is something that makes me crazy.

But it makes me even crazier people who dedicate theis lives to devote to it.

Thats why im going to analyse that people. I'll talk about their ages, countries, weight, height, best athletes...

Do you want to accompany me on this trip?

  • 1. Data exploration
  • 2. Men and women in the Olympic Games
  • 3. Top Men in Olympic Games
  • 4. Top Women in Olympic Games
  • 5. Top countries with medals
  • 6. Age distribution in Olympic Games
  • 7. Height and weight distribution in Olympic Games
  • 8. Top host cities in Olympic Games

source.d47e2ae2: Now we are going to see mens with the highest number of gold medals in the Olympics history

Anyway, in the plot we see strange decreases in 1976 and 1980
